DIV1.P: ATHELSTAN. A TRAGEDY. As it is ACTED at the THEATRE ROYAL in Drury-Lane.
LONDON, Printed for LOCKYER DAVIS and CHARLES REYMERS, against Grays-Inn-Gate, Holbourn; And at Lord Bacon's Head in Fleet-Street. MDCCLVI. [Price One Shilling and Six-pence.]

IL ne faut pourtant pas croire que les Grecs manquent de Feu. Tout s'anime au con∣traire, tout parle, tout agit dans leurs Ecrits. Mais c'est plus l'Action & le Spectacle que les Paroles, & plus la Passion & le Sentiment que le Discours; au lieu que les François ont souvent donné dans le Discours & les Paroles pour sup∣pleer au Spectacle ou à la Passion. Combien de Portraits, de Sentences, & de Lieux communs bien frappés, ont arraché des Applaudissemens qui devoient être réservés à l'emotion Theatrale qu'on ne sentoit pas? ce n'est que le sang froid qui applaudit à la Beauté des Vers dans un Spec∣tacle.

DIV1.HEAD: TO HIS GRACE The Duke of DEVONSHIRE, Lord Lieutenant of Ireland.
DIV1.P: IT was the frequent Practice of the ancient Greek Tragedians, to make their Compositions for the Theatre subservient to the Welfare of the State. The Legislator's Wis∣dom was inforced by the Poet's Art. Public Guilt was stigmatized, and public Virtue applauded. Of this Kind somewhat is, or ought to be, shadowed out in the following Tra∣gedy.
But it may possibly be asked, "Why this Address from a Writer who is, and determines to remain, unknown?"

My LORD, it comes from one, who, altho' he hath not wanted Op∣portunities, hath ever scorned to pro∣stitute Addresses of this Kind to Views of Interest. But if it hath for once happened in his Time, that Virtue and Power are eminently united; his honest Disdain of offering Incense to the one, shall not intimi∣date him from avowing his Reve∣rence of the other.

More especially, the natural Re∣lation which the Design of this Tra∣gedy bears to your Grace's Conduct, gives its Author a kind of equitable Title, without Leave, to prefix your Name. Thus, while he delineates Rebellion, he contrasts it with true Loyalty: And to an Example of Se∣dition
drawn from ancient Days, op∣poses a Character from modern Life, who in the highest Station, and most perilous Times, hath been the Re∣storer of Unity and Concord.

CLOSER.SIGNED: I am, My LORD, with the highest Esteem, your GRACE's most obedient Servant, The AUTHOR.

DIV1.HEAD: PROLOGUE;
DIV1.BYLINE: Written by the AUTHOR of the TRAGEDY.
DIV1.STAGE: Spoken by Mr. HOLLAND in the Character, of the Genius of Britain.

LG.L: TO warn the Sons of Freedom to be wise,
Lo, Britain's guardian Genius quits the Skies,
With Pity, Heav'n hath seen thro' many an Age,
The bold Invader lur'd by Faction's Rage;
Seen the dark Workings of Rebellion's Train,
While Patriots plann'd, and Heroes bled in vain.
Behold, your Country's faithless Foe, once more
With threatning Squadrons crowd yon hostile Shore.
Behold Oppression's bloody Flag unfurl'd:
See Bolts prepar'd, to chain the Western World.
Rise, Britons, rise! to Heav'n and Virtue true:
Expiring Liberty looks up to You!
Pour on the common Foe your Rage combin'd,
And be the Friends of Freedom and Mankind!
No more let Discord Britain's Peace destroy;
Nor spurn those Blessings, Reason bids enjoy:
Oh, weigh those Blessings in her equal Scale!—
Say;—When did Justice wear a whiter Veil?
When did Religion gentler Looks disclose,
To bless her Friends, and pity ev'n her Foes?
A richer Harvest when did Commerce reap?
When rode your Flects more dreadful o'er the Deep?
Or when more bright (hear, Envy! hear, and own!)
Did Truth, did Honour beam from Britain's Throne?
Seize then the Happiness deny'd your Foes:
Nor blindly scorn the Gifts which Heav'n bestows:
Gifts, the World's Envy! happy Britain's Pride!
For which, your generous Fathers toil'd and dy'd!
Let Union lift the Sword, direct the Blow,
And hurl a Nation's Vengeance on its Foe!
As your bold Cliffs, when Tides and Tempests roar,
Fling back the mad'ning Billows from the Shore.
One Head, one Heart, one Arm, one People, rise!
Nor fall, divided Valour's Sacrifice!—
But if, by Hope of proud Invasion led,
Unaw'd Rebellion lift her gory Head;—
Treason, attend!—here view the Rebel's Fate;
Nor hope, thy Arm can shake a free-born State:
See Blood and Horror end what Guilt began;
And tremble at thy Woes, in Athelstan.

DIV1.HEAD: The PERSONS.
DIV1.P: SCENE, the Danish Camp near London. Time, from the Evening, till Midnight.

SP.SPEAKER: HAROLD.
SP.L: GOTHMUND a Warrior? By our Gods of Denmark,
I cou'd have sack'd ten Cities since the Morn.
The lingering Sun goes down, and yet beholds
The Danish Sword hang pow'rless o'er the Foe.
DUNELM, well met.—What means this vile Delay?
What hast thou seen?

SP.SPEAKER: DUNELM.
SP.L: From yonder Eminence,
Ev'n now, I saw proud London wrapt in Fire.
HAROLD, behold yon dusky Wreaths of Smoke:
Yon pitchy Cloud is fraught with glorious Ruin.

SP.SPEAKER: HAROLD.
SP.L: Indeed!

SP.SPEAKER: DUNELM.
SP.L: I saw the Flames besiege the Tow'r
Which proudly had scorn'd the general Assault
Of Denmark's Pow'r. Soon spread the sulphur'd Fires,
Mining it's Base: at length, with horrid Crash,
The Pile fell headlong, like a Wreck of Nature.
And as it fell, a hollow Murmur pierc'd
Mine Ear, that seem'd an Army's dying Groan.
I saw the Breach in the proud City's Wall,
Where our brave Danes pour'd in, while Shouts of Conquest
Dismay'd the flying Rear. HAROLD, ere this,
The City's won.

SP.SPEAKER: HAROLD.
SP.L: No more—I'm sorry for't.

SP.SPEAKER: DUNELM.
SP.L: What! when our Troops thro' ten long Moons have toil'd,
Till Siege and fell Disease have thin'd our Ranks,
Before this Capital, this haughty London,
The Mistress of the Island. When her Tow'rs
Are humbled in the Dust! ev'n then to wear
That clouded Eye! Much it might suit a Briton;
But ill becomes a Dane.

SP.SPEAKER: HAROLD.
SP.L: Have I not Cause
To hate our General?

SP.SPEAKER: DUNELM.
SP.L: Grant it: yet no Cause
To hate the Victories his Sword hath gain'd
For Denmark's Weal.

SP.SPEAKER: HAROLD.
SP.L: Dishonour blast his Laurels!
Ere since I won full Glory from our Wars,
He checks my Valour, lest it should o'ertop,
And shadow his—Behold, this very Day,
When mighty London falls a Prey to Denmark,
I'm pent within the Circuit of a Camp,
On an obscure and ignominious Charge.
My Sword, inglorious, sleeps within its Scabbard,
Depriv'd its Prey. Yes: well he knew, this Arm
Had led the Storm: as erst it did, to him
And his Compeers; when Norway's frozen Cities
Sunk at my Frown; when thro' conflicting Hosts
I op'd the dreadful Track; while far behind
He loyter'd in the Breach, and poorly reap'd
The Gleanings of my Faulcion.

SP.SPEAKER: DUNELM.
SP.L: Peace, brave HAROLD.
Nor let Dissention blot the gen'ral Triumph.

SP.SPEAKER: HAROLD.
SP.L: Here, DUNELM, here shall deep Revenge lie pent,
Must'ring it's Rage: but soon th' impatient Flood
Shall burst the Mound, and overwhelm his Pride.
Yes: may I ne'er more win the Wreath of Conquest;
Ne'er fall triumphant in the Field of Fame;
But groan out Life, stretch'd on th' unmanly Couch;
If I repay not GOTHMUND's uncaus'd Hate,
With deadliest Vengeance!

SP.SPEAKER: DUNELM.
SP.L: Let thy Vengeance wait
Some darker Hour.—Behold, where GOODWIN comes.
His Eye speaks Victory: and his glad Step
Prevents the welcome Tidings of his Tongue.

SP.SPEAKER: GOODWIN.
SP.L: Hail, valiant HAROLD! This great Day shall shine
In Denmark's Annals. GOTHMUND sends thee greeting;
With the glad News of England's Overthrow.
Himself shall soon arrive.

SP.SPEAKER: HAROLD.
SP.L: Brave GOODWIN, welcome:
More welcome for thy Tidings. London then,
England's chief Boast, is fall'n.—

SP.SPEAKER: GOODWIN.
SP.L: Ev'n now it burns.
See yon ascending Clouds. Yon pillar'd Smoke,
That hides the Welkin, is it's last Remain.
The English Pow'rs have left the bleeding Ramparts;
The wide Breach choak'd with Heaps of Slain, on which
We mounted to the Storm.

SP.SPEAKER: HAROLD.
SP.L: How went the Day?
Where fought our Gen'ral GOTHMUND?

SP.SPEAKER: GOODWIN.
SP.L: On the Thames.
Soon as the Signal of Assault was given,
The Danish Fleet came on. Our Standard then,
The Raven, hov'ring on his Wing, appear'd
With ominous Glare; and seem'd to croak Destruction.
Then furious GOTHMUND, from the crowded Decks
Follow'd by shouting Thousands, leapt to Shore
With ruinous Assault:

SP.SPEAKER: HAROLD.
SP.L: What? no Resistance?

SP.SPEAKER: GOODWIN.
SP.L: Yes; bloody was the Fray: The Scale of War
Hung doubtful; till the mighty ATHELSTAN,
Mercia's brave Duke, to Denmark's aid came on;
Spur'd by a keen Revenge more strong than Glory,
Led his revolted Mercians up the Breach,
And mingled in the Storm.

SP.SPEAKER: HAROLD.
SP.L: What next ensu'd?

SP.SPEAKER: GOODWIN.
SP.L: Confusion and wild Rout. For England's Pow'r,
Dreading the vengeful Sword of ATHELSTAN,
Shrunk from his Rage: then Denmark's Star prevail'd:
The Britons fled: and now, by Right of War,
The City's Wealth, it's captive Youth and Virgins,
Are fall'n the Soldiers Plunder.

SP.SPEAKER: HAROLD.
SP.L: It seems then, GOTHMUND owes full half his Conquest
To ATHELSTAN's Revenge.

SP.SPEAKER: GOODWIN.
SP.L: Aye, more than half.
Ne'er did such deadly Valour sweep the Field:
His hoary Head clasp'd in a steel rib'd Helm,
He sprung to Vengeance, and forgot old Age.
With such a headlong Course he led the War,
That Denmark's Troops, nay his own firey Mercians
Linger'd behind: while he, attended only
By Death and Fate, which at his right Hand rag'd,
Thin'd the retreating Foe.

SP.SPEAKER: HAROLD.
SP.L: Thank we the Gods,
Who sow Dissention in these British Hearts!
Else, ne'er had this fair City fall'n our Prey!

SP.SPEAKER: DUNELM.
SP.L: Know ye the Cause why this proud Duke of Mercia
Revolted from his King?

SP.SPEAKER: GOODWIN.
SP.L: Pride and Revenge.
Some suit deny'd him, which the royal Bounty,
Unequal to the Cravings of it's People,
Granted his Foe. No more. His firey Spirit
Mounted to sudden Rage: with secret Levy
He muster'd all his Pow'rs, and join'd with Denmark
To overwhelm his Country.

SP.SPEAKER: HAROLD.
SP.L: Be it ours,
To nurse this useful Treason: Thus invading,
While we divide, we conquer.

SP.SPEAKER: DUNELM.
SP.L: Hark! I hear
The Shouts of Victory.

SP.SPEAKER: GOODWIN.
SP.L: GOTHMUND approaches.
His Troops come laden with the precious Spoil
Of this imperial City. Captive Maids,
The sweet Reward of Valour, grace his Triumph:
And Infants, doom'd to drink the bitter Draught
Of endless Slavery in a foreign Clime.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE III.
DIV2.STAGE: To them, GOTHMUND in Triumph. A Train of Prisoners. And EGBERT in Chains, as a Prisoner.

SP.SPEAKER: HAROLD.
SP.L: Hail, valiant GOTHMUND! Denmark's proudest Boast!
Whom mighty ODIN, the dread God of War,
Hath crown'd with England's Conquest!

SP.SPEAKER: GOTHMUND.
SP.L: Faithful HAROLD,
The City's won. London, whose haughty Tow'rs
We shook so long with terrible Assault,
At length is fall'n, and blazes to the Sky.
'Twas Pity, HAROLD, on so great a Day,
When the rich Plunder of the War was seiz'd,
Thy Valour lost it's Prey. But fair Division
Of our acquired Spoil, of Wealth and Captives,
Shall bring thee Recompense.

SP.SPEAKER: HAROLD.
SP.L: I thank thee, Gen'ral.
Devoted to thy Will, I held my Charge,
To guard our Camp from the out-sallying Foe:
A Charge less splendid than the Post in Battle;
Yet, as conducing to the general Weal,
No whit less honourable.

SP.SPEAKER: GOTHMUND.
SP.L: HAROLD, behold
This Train of Captives: to thy Charge I give them:
But chiefly that stern Youth, whose Arm oppos'd
Singly to mine, long held the Conflict doubtful.
No common Ransom shall redeem him hence.
Why dost thou frown?

SP.SPEAKER: EGBERT.
SP.L: Because I dare to scorn
My Country's Foe.

SP.SPEAKER: GOTHMUND.
SP.L: So haughty in thy Chains?
What Title bear'st thou?

SP.SPEAKER: EGBERT.
SP.L: 'Tis enough for thee,
To know me still a Briton: thence to fear me.

SP.SPEAKER: GOTHMUND.
SP.L: A Conqu'ror fear his Captive! By our Gods,
Speak but another Word, audacious Christian,
I'll plunge thee in the deep Norwegian Mine,
Among these Slaves the Vassals of my Sword,
To toil in Darkness thro' the live-long Year,
Till baleful Damps consume thee.

SP.SPEAKER: EGBERT.
SP.L: Yes: bury me in Darkness; in the Depth,
Where Slavery drinks the pestilential Vapour;
For that I've liv'd to see my Country's Fall!
I dare thee to the Deed, rapacious Dane!
But well I know, thy Hand expects the Ransom;
Nor aught but Av'rice chains thy Cruelty.

SP.SPEAKER: GOTHMUND.
SP.L: What? Shall I waste the Hours in fruitless Parle
With an audacious Slave!—Lo, Mercia's Duke
Comes with his warlike Train. Retire, ye Slaves;
And at an awful Distance bow to Valour.—
This firey ATHELSTAN! Yes, I cou'd curse
His Sword victorious, and wide wasting Arm
That blasted all my Wreaths; and won the Praise
Of this eventful Day!—Hence envious Fame
Shall tarnish GOTHMUND's Glory; while she whispers,
Orhaply to the listning World proclaims,
That Britain conquer'd Britain.—Come; fell Hate!
Pour all thy Poison on my Heart; and turn
Friendship to Enmity!—Should he revolt?—
The Rebel dare not: Nor can e'er repass
The Gulph which he hath leapt; and severs him
For ever from his Country.—Yet 'tis meet
That Prudence greet him with fair Speech, and Smiles;
Till some desir'd Occasion yield Pretence,
And spurn him off, to Shame.—
Let Denmark's Raven wave his dreadful Wing,
To hail the glad Approach of ATHELSTAN:
And sound, in Honour of our firm Ally,
The Instruments of War.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE IV.
DIV2.STAGE: To them, ATHELSTAN; with his Train.

SP.SPEAKER: GOTHMUND.
SP.L: I greet thee, ATHELSTAN. Thy mighty Arm,
On this great Day, hath sham'd it's former Doings.
Thro' the red Tracks of Death I saw thee seek
The King. His Troops, stricken with coward Guilt,
Fled trembling at the Sight of injur'd Valour
Wak'd into Wrath. Yes, wondring Denmark saw,
How Terror stalk'd before thee thro' the Streets,
While thy broad Faulcion flam'd; and dread Revenge
Frown'd on thy Helm like Fate.

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: No Flattery, GOTHMUND.
Balm to the Fool's, it wounds the brave Man's Ear.
My Sword hath reap'd sull Vengeance on its Foes;
And vanquish'd ETHELRED with Tears and Groans
Shall rue the Wrongs he did me.

SP.SPEAKER: GOTHMUND.
SP.L: Valiant Duke,
Such Vengeance well became such Wrongs as thine.

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: My Wrongs were loud for Vengeance. Pity wept:
But Reason choak'd her Voice:—For awful Justice
Must drop her Sword, unnerve her lifted Arm,
Unbridled Pow'r turn Order into Chaos,
Shou'd Pity melt at proud Oppression's Fall.—
What Youth is that, who from the captive Throng
Comes forth with haughty Strides?

SP.SPEAKER: GOTHMUND.
SP.L: An unknown Briton:
Yet fierce in Battle; for his Sword was fatal
To many a Dane; and midst the falling Ranks
Rag'd like a Whirlwind. Mark his fearless Mien.
He wears the Pride of Conquest, tho' in Chains.
His Eye devours thee, ATHELSTAN.—

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: I reck not.
Let him come on: I'll meet his Pride unmov'd.
Who dares to frown on ATHELSTAN?

SP.SPEAKER: EGBERT.
SP.L: A Briton.

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: Who art thou?

SP.SPEAKER: EGBERT.
SP.L: One, who heedless of thy Rage,
Dares throw his Scorn on Guilt.

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: Audacious Captive!
Think'st thou I fear thy frown?

SP.SPEAKER: EGBERT.
SP.L: Oh, bleeding England!
Behold thy fatal Foe!

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: Weep'st thou, brave Youth?
Tho' I have pour'd Destruction on thy King,
I wage no War with Captives. Gen'rous Warrior,
My Pow'r shall shield thee, and unbind thy Chains.

SP.SPEAKER: EGBERT.
SP.L: Stand off.—I chuse to wear them.

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: Why that Choice?

SP.SPEAKER: EGBERT.
SP.L: Lest these brave captive Britons, shackled there,
Should brand me for a Traitor.

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: Heed thee well.
Think what thou art, and where.—

SP.SPEAKER: EGBERT.
SP.L: Thank Heav'n,
I am not ATHELSTAN!

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: Nay, I can frown too.—

SP.SPEAKER: EGBERT.
SP.L: Blush,—rather blush! The crimson Hue of Shame
Wou'd better suit thy Crimes!

SP.SPEAKER: GOTHMUND.
SP.L: Peace, arrogant Youth!

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: Who gave to thee this Privilege of Scorn?
This Right of Insult and bold Accusation?

SP.SPEAKER: EGBERT.
SP.L: That Pow'r who gave me Reason and Humanity:
That awful Pow'r Above, who bids me dare
To strip false Treason of her Mask of Pride;
And shew the Hag, in her own Shape and Hue,
The foulest Fiend of Hell.

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: Thy Chains protect thee!

SP.SPEAKER: GOTHMUND.
SP.L: GOODWIN, lead forth these Captives to the Fleet;
And let the first fair Breeze that fills the Sail
Waft them to Denmark's Shore.—HAROLD, bear hence,
And guard that Insolent.

SP.SPEAKER: EGBERT.
SP.L: Farewell, brave Friends!
My faithful Countrymen! I weep your Fate,
Doom'd to th' Oppressions of a barbarous Clime!
Oh, may some friendly Storm in Pity rise,
And bid the Fury of devouring Seas
In Mercy swallow you!—Accursed Treason!
Lo, thy devoted Train! Oh false, false ATHELSTAN!

DIV2.STAGE: [Ex. EGBERT, HAROLD, GOODWIN, DUNELM, and Captives.

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: Go, froward Briton!

SP.SPEAKER: GOTHMUND.
SP.L: Valiant ATHELSTAN,
Heed not a Captive's Clamour. Denmark now
Boasts thee her Friend. And for undoubted Proof
Of that Esteem, wherewith I note thy Valour;
Behold the precious Spoils my Arm hath won
Amid the gen'ral Plunder: Gold or Captives,
Lands, Palaces, whate'er inventive Passion
Can fancy for Enjoyment, waits thy Will:
Command it; for 'tis thine.

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: Of Gold, or Lands,
The Plunder of the War, I reck not aught.
For, to the noble Mind, a great Revenge
Outweighs all other Good. This I have reap'd
Full-measur'd; Of my thankless Country's Blood
My Sword hath drank, ev'n to Satiety:
No other Boon it craves.

SP.SPEAKER: GOTHMUND.
SP.L: Brave ATHELSTAN,
Ev'n as thou wilt.—Has then no precious Spoil
Inrich'd thy Valour?

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: Yes: one beauteous Captive,
Won in the City's Storm: and now consign'd
To SIWARD's Care, a brave and faithful Friend,
Who leads her hitherward. So winning sweet!
The surly Troops gaz'd on her as she pass'd,
And Silence spoke their Wonder.

SP.SPEAKER: GOTHMUND.
SP.L: Such a Fair
May haply mourn in secret; that her Lot
Fell to thy aged Arm. Some youthful Warrior
Might better suit her Wish.

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: I mean, to shield her
From the rude Will of insolent Desire.

SP.SPEAKER: GOTHMUND.
SP.L: Indeed!

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: Indeed.—It was her chaste Request.
And mark me: Tho' my Arm hath quell'd it's Foes,
Yet ATHELSTAN would blush, to wreak his Vengeance
On a defenceless Woman.

SP.SPEAKER: GOTHMUND.
SP.L: By what Chance
Did'st thou obtain this Captive?

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: While the Storm
Rag'd in the Streets; Fate led my conqu'ring Band,
Where this fair Captive mourn'd the Lot of War.
I found her kneeling; with uplifted Eyes,
And Majesty resign'd, imploring Heav'n.
Rouz'd by the Shouts of War, she rose: Her Train
Fill'd all the Place with female Lamentation:
But she, in Grief superior, check'd their Cries,
And grac'd her Woes with regal Dignity.
With such a noble Mien she su'd for Mercy,
That Vengeance stood subdu'd: while nameless Graces,
Beauty, and Mildness, and majestic Grief,
Like Guardian Pow'rs which Heav'n had planted round her,
Check'd the rude Access of unhallow'd Rage:
That ev'n the Sons of Violence drop'd the Sword,
To gaze at awful Distance.—Tow'rd her Tent,
This Way she moves with her attendant Train.
Behold her here.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE V.
DIV2.STAGE: To them, THYRA, EDWINA, SIWARD, and female Attendants.

SP.SPEAKER: GOTHMUND.
SP.L: Indeed, supremely fair.

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: THYRA, be comforted: Nay, dry these Tears.
Else shall I deem my too officious Cares
Lost on a thankless Heart.

SP.SPEAKER: THYRA.
SP.L: Oh, ATHELSTAN!
Whose Mercy speaks thee brave! Forgive these Tears.
For my dear Lord, to me than Life more dear,
These Sorrows flow!—Indeed, my thankful Heart
Melts in warm Gratitude to thy kind Care,
Which sav'd me from the Horrors of this Day.
But, Oh!—my Husband!

SP.SPEAKER: GOTHMUND.
SP.L: Why these streaming Tears?
What of her Husband? Did he fall in Battle?

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: That is her Fear:
Tho' Rumour yet speak doubtful of his Fate.

SP.SPEAKER: THYRA.
SP.L: Too sure, he's fall'n!—Ye gen'rous Warriors, hear,—
Hear a poor Captive's Pray'r!—Oh, let your Guards
Conduct my faithful Servants to the Field:
Or give me Safe-guard thro' the deathful Scene;
I will divest me of my Woman's Fear,
And with a Scythian Boldness tread in Gore;
Drag off the Heaps of overwhelming Foes,
Till I have found my EGBERT's dear Remains,
To give them Burial. The last, mournful Duty
I e'er can pay his Love.

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: Despond not, Fair one:
Haply, he yet may live.

SP.SPEAKER: THYRA.
SP.L: Oh, flatt'ring Hope!
Grant me but That!—But That, ye Pow'rs of Heav'n!

SP.SPEAKER: GOTHMUND.
SP.L: Now, by our Gods of Denmark, ATHELSTAN,
This is too bright a Fair, for Age like thine
Idly to gaze on.

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: Beauty, thus afflicted,
Merits my Pow'r's Protection.

SP.SPEAKER: GOTHMUND.
SP.L: Is she not
The Captive of thy Sword?

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: True, but the Sword
That won, shall guard her.

SP.SPEAKER: GOTHMUND.
SP.L: What if GOTHMUND's Will
Shou'd raise this Fair one from the captive Throng,
To grace his Bed?

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: By Law of War she's mine;
And I have sworn Protection.

SP.SPEAKER: GOTHMUND.
SP.L: From thy Foe
To shield thy Captive, were a Task of Praise
Worthy thy Arm. But when a true Ally,
Thy Friend in War, intreats so small a Boon—

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: GOTHMUND, the Friend whose erring Wish demands
What Honour cannot yield—I pray, no more—

SP.SPEAKER: GOTHMUND.
SP.L: If GOTHMUND's Friendship, in thy thankless Heart,
Insensible to all my proffer'd Bounty,
Stands at so cheap a Price—Protect thy Captive.—
Let thy Pow'r shield her as it may.—Lead on.—

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: Imperious Dane! Would'st thou bend ATHELSTAN
Beneath thy Pride?—His parting Words and Looks
Darted Contempt.—This the Reward of Conquest?
This, Valour's Recompense?

SP.SPEAKER: SIWARD.
SP.L: 'Twas what I fear'd.—
Why did Revenge seduce thee from thy King!
Bear Witness, Heav'n, if e'er I trod the Field,
Or bar'd my Sword in seeming Aid of Denmark,
Save in the honest Hope, to check thy Vengeance.

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: What? To a thankless King, a favour'd Foe
Basking beneath the royal Smile, to yield
With coward-like Submission?—Friend, no more.
The Dye of Fate is thrown.

SP.SPEAKER: SIWARD.
SP.L: Didst thou not see,
How Passion kindled, while with ardent Gaze
He ey'd fair THYRA's Charms? His Soul hath caught
A swift and deep Infection. Mark th' Event.

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: Weak is thy Fear. Tho' bold in Violence,
He dare not wake my Rage.

SP.SPEAKER: THYRA.
SP.L: Oh gen'rous Duke,
Behold me at thy Feet! I see the Storm
Fast gath'ring o'er my Head! Redeem, redeem me
From this rapacious Dane! I dread not Death;
Whose Image, from my earliest Age of Woe,
Hath been the calm Companion of my Thoughts.
Then let thy Arm, which on this fatal Morn
Did shield me, now compleat it's gen'rous Care.
My forfeit Life is thine. In Pity kill me,
Ere yet Dishonour blot my Innocence.

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: By my good Sword, which won thee in the Storm,
Again I swear, not Denmark's proudest Threat
Shall wrest thee from me.—SIWARD, are my Mercians
Camp'd in their separate Quarter?

SP.SPEAKER: SIWARD.
SP.L: Aye, my Lord:
Westward, a Mile; on a fair rising Ground,
Fast by the River's Brink.

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: This Night I meant
To pass in Council with the General GOTHMUND,
On future Enterprize. But since his Pride
Brooks no Controul;—wou'd Heav'n I had not come!
Since it is thus:—At least his Pride shall seek me:
And if I find him bent on Violence,
The Morning Sun shall see me quit his Camp.
Hast thou prepar'd fair THYRA's Tent by mine?

SP.SPEAKER: SIWARD.
SP.L: I did command it so.

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: Retire we then.

SP.SPEAKER: THYRA.
SP.L: I merit not thy Care. Why shou'd I live,
When my dear Lord is lost, and England fall'n!

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: Touch not on That:—For by this Arm it fell.
Yes: I have wash'd my Footsteps in the Blood
Of my despairing Foes.—But oh, for whom!
I'll think no more.—Come, THYRA, to thy Tent.

SP.SPEAKER: GOTHMUND.
SP.L: HAST thou not seen her, HAROLD?

SP.SPEAKER: HAROLD.
SP.L: Much I have heard.
Her Beauty dwells on ev'ry Soldier's Tongue,
And half eclipses Conquest.

SP.SPEAKER: GOTHMUND.
SP.L: Oh, such Beauty!
HAROLD, her Eye's bright Beam might thaw the cold
Norwegian's Breast; or warm the frozen Sons
Of Lapland into Love.—Oh Earth and Heav'n!
My Soul's on Fire!—The Glories of the War,
The Wreaths of Conquest sicken on her Sight.
Avaunt, Ambition! yield thy Throne to Love!
HAROLD, she must be mine.

SP.SPEAKER: HAROLD.
SP.L: What lets thee then?
What Bar so strong, to guard her from thy Wish?
Each cobweb Hindrance to thy Breath shall yield,
If thou but will her Thine.

SP.SPEAKER: GOTHMUND.
SP.L: May I ne'er taste the Warrior's Lot in Death,
Ne'er quaff the rich Meath in th' infernal Courts,
Where mighty ODIN rules the glorious Dead,
If I not seize her Beauties.—But, brave HAROLD,
This delicate Captive is no common Food,
Like what we snatch in ev'ry City's Plunder,
For gross Desire to seed on. I wou'd win
Her Soul's Consent: wou'd kindle mutual Passion,
To meet my Flame: At least, by fair Persuasion
Wou'd temper Pow'r; that the Effect might seem
Without all Shew of Violence. HAROLD, haste thee
To the fair Captive's Tent. Tell her, the Gods
Of Denmark claim their wonted Sacrifice
Of captive Youths, and thirst for England's Gore.
But if her dear Consent shall crown my Wish,
Our Gods propitious will accept her Smile,
In Ransom for their Blood. Paint forth the Terrors
Of the dread Sacrifice; the Victims bound;
The howling Incantations of our Priests
Invoking Hell; the glittering Faulcion bar'd;
The streaming Gore, and Horrors of the Altar.
The mournful Tale shall melt her into Grief,
And Pity plead Consent.

SP.SPEAKER: HAROLD.
SP.L: I wait thy Will.
Yet were my Counsel worthy GOTHMUND's Ear—

SP.SPEAKER: GOTHMUND.
SP.L: What woud'st thou?—Say.—

SP.SPEAKER: HAROLD.
SP.L: Some captive Briton best
Wou'd bend her Pride.

SP.SPEAKER: GOTHMUND.
SP.L: Not so. These stubborn Britons,
Unconquer'd ev'n in Chains, defy our Swords;
Awful in Ruin: Like their kindred Oaks,
Tho' blasted by the Thunder of the War,
They proudly bear their scorched Ribs aloft,
And brave the Pow'r that struck them. Therefore, HA∣ROLD,
That Hope is vain.

SP.SPEAKER: HAROLD.
SP.L: Persuasion, sure, wou'd flow
Prompt, and more pow'rful from some Captive's Tongue,
To Death or endless Slav'ry doom'd; yet sooth'd
With Hope, and promis'd Freedom. For the Speech
Of mimic Art is weak and sinewless,
To the strong Workings of the lab'ring Soul,
When Passion glows within.

SP.SPEAKER: GOTHMUND.
SP.L: 'Tis well advis'd.
Then lead some captive Briton to her Tent,
On this great Purpose. But o'er all I fear
This haughty ATHELSTAN: He claims her His,
By Law of Battle; and hath sworn Protection.

SP.SPEAKER: HAROLD.
SP.L: Is GOTHMUND's Pow'r so weak, then, that he dreads
A Traitor's Frown?

SP.SPEAKER: GOTHMUND.
SP.L: Nay, by our Gods, I'll seize her;
Tho' he, and all the witching Pow'rs of Hell,
Tho' the weird Sisters, and each horrible Shape
That haunts the midnight Forest, hemm her round
With Magick Incantation.—HAROLD, speed thee.
I'll wait thee in my Tent.—

SP.SPEAKER: HAROLD.
SP.L: Now, Spirit of Mischief, rise! Welcome, foul Fiend,
That rid'st the Carr of Night; and scatter'st Plagues
With unseen Hand!—DUNELM, he fears me not:
Nor dreams what Tempest soon shall blacken round.
Did'st thou not mark that frowning Captive, EGBERT?

SP.SPEAKER: DUNELM.
SP.L: I did.

SP.SPEAKER: HAROLD.
SP.L: He best will bear the General's Love
To THYRA's Tent.—Command him hither, DUNELM.
His gen'rous Heart shall burn with fierce Disdain;
And strengthen THYRA's Virtue into Scorn,
Which Pity cannot bend.—So black a Purpofe
Known and proclaim'd, may haply rouze to Rage
The Duke of Mercia; in whose fiery Breast
Lies Fury, ripe to catch, and blaze in Flames.
Oh, for some swift Occasion, that my Breath
May kindle Discord into deadly Feud!
Like angry Clouds that sail on warring Winds,
Their sierce conflicting Wrath shall meet in Thunder,
And Ruin close the Fray!—

SP.SPEAKER: HAROLD.
SP.L: Welcome, brave Youth.
Thy Fame, and known Pre-eminence in Valour,
Have call'd thee to a generous Task of Duty,
For Britain's Weal.—Thou know'st, by Doom of War,
Full fifty Captives to our Gods must bleed.

SP.SPEAKER: EGBERT.
SP.L: So doom your fancy'd Gods, the vain Creation
Of Fear and Cruelty. But righteous Heav'n,
That sees your Blindness with a pitying Eye,
Detests the Sacrifice.

SP.SPEAKER: HAROLD.
SP.L: Prevent it then.

SP.SPEAKER: EGBERT.
SP.L: Name but the Means. If my devoted Blood
Can save my guiltless Countrymen from Death,
I yield it to the Altar.

SP.SPEAKER: HAROLD.
SP.L: Valiant EGBERT,
A gentler Task is thine. A captive Beauty
Brightens yon Tent: She hath subdu'd our General.
The Rage of Love is on him. If thy Tongue
Can win her to his Bed.—

SP.SPEAKER: EGBERT.
SP.L: HAROLD, no more.
Think'st thou, because I drag the Chain of War,
My Soul must wear your Shackles? Fall'n a Captive,
I bear a Briton's Heart: The Coward only
Earns Safety by Dishonour.

SP.SPEAKER: HAROLD.
SP.L: Yet many a Briton
Wou'd deem it Service, worth a brave Man's Care,
To save devoted Innocence from Death,
At this cheap Price. Weigh'd with the Blood of Man,
What is this unknown Woman's Weal or Woe,
This captive THYRA's Honour?

SP.SPEAKER: EGBERT.
SP.L: THYRA?—THYRA?
What THYRA?

SP.SPEAKER: HAROLD.
SP.L: ATHELSTAN's fair Captive THYRA.
What Terror's in that Name? What wonder moves thee?

SP.SPEAKER: EGBERT.
SP.L: Ye Pow'rs of Heav'n!—HAROLD, if thou'rt a Man;
If ever brave Compassion touch'd thy Breast;
If e'er the tender Names of Wife and Husband,
The bleeding Anguish of despairing Virtue,
The Love of Worth, or Piety to Heav'n,
Did sway thy Heart to great and gen'rous Deeds,
Or melted thee to Pity, hear me now!
That THYRA is my Wife!

SP.SPEAKER: HAROLD.
SP.L: Indeed? thy Wife?

SP.SPEAKER: EGBERT.
SP.L: So sure, as Infamy is hov'ring o'er her,
My Wife! Devoted to this Ruffian's Lust!

SP.SPEAKER: HAROLD.
SP.L: EGBERT, I love the Valour of a Foe:
And Worth like thine turns Enmity to Praise.
How will thy Bosom burn with honest Rage,
When hissing Scorn proclaims—

SP.SPEAKER: EGBERT.
SP.L: Oh, thou hast shook
My firmest Fortitude! I thought her dead.
When she was lost, what more cou'd EGBERT fear?
Hence cold Despair had gather'd o'er my Soul,
Wrap'd it in Ice from ev'ry Sense of Ill,
And chain'd the struggling Tear. But her lov'd Name
Hath rouz'd me from this Lethargy of Woe,
Hath thaw'd the frozen Horrors of my Heart,
And melted me to Childhood. Grief and Joy,
And Fear, and Hope, in tumult rise within me:
While thro' the moistened Chanels of mine Eyes
These Sorrows flow:—Yes, for thy Sake, thy EGBERT
Weeps his Captivity!

SP.SPEAKER: HAROLD.
SP.L: Waste not in Tears
The precious Minutes. Speed thee to her Tent.
Dishonour and Pollution hover o'er it.

SP.SPEAKER: EGBERT.
SP.L: Perdition seize the Robber! Gen'rous HAROLD,
Lead me to aid this helpless Innocence.
Hear me, brave Countrymen! and witness Heav'n,
That to redeem your death-devoted Blood,
EGBERT wou'd yield his own—But oh, my Wife!
What! yield her to a Russian's Lust?—Nay rather,
I'll dash her Beauties into Wounds and Horror,
For Lust to start at.—Lead me to her Tent.
My lab'ring Heart will burst!

SP.SPEAKER: HAROLD.
SP.L: Th' attending Guard
Shall guide thee to her Tent.

SP.SPEAKER: THYRA, EDWINA.
SP.L: Sure, 'tis some warning Pow'r that whispers here.
My beating Heart forebodes th' Approach of Fate,
And labours with th' Event.—EDWINA, come:
Friend of my Life, dear Partner of my Woes!
Teach me to combat these surrounding Terrors,
That overwhelm my Soul!

SP.SPEAKER: EDWINA.
SP.L: Take Comfort, THYRA:
All may be well.

SP.SPEAKER: THYRA.
SP.L: Oh, this unpitying Dane!
Raging with Insolence, and red with Slaughter!
What cannot he attempt!

SP.SPEAKER: EDWINA.
SP.L: Distrust not Heav'n.
The valiant ATHELSTAN hath vow'd Protection.
Wrong not his generous Care.

SP.SPEAKER: THYRA.
SP.L: May ev'ry Pow'r
That watches o'er the just and brave, protect him,
And crown his Days with Honour!

SP.SPEAKER: DUNELM.
SP.L: Beauteous Captive,
A Messenger from GOTHMUND—

SP.SPEAKER: THYRA.
SP.L: Oh, my Fears!

SP.SPEAKER: DUNELM.
SP.L: He wills, that all depart,
Save only Thee: for he hath much to say,
Meet for thy private Ear.

SP.SPEAKER: THYRA.
SP.L: Alas, EDWINA!
What shall I do! Oh leave me not, EDWINA!
Undone, undone!

SP.SPEAKER: DUNELM.
SP.L: Nay, weep not, beauteous Captive.
Let all depart; else ye provoke his Rage▪

SP.SPEAKER: THYRA.
SP.L: Now which Way shall I turn me! Whither fly
To shun these gathering Horrors!—Wou'd I had fallen
Beneath the Battle's Fury! That the Spear
Had pierc'd my Heart! Or that some flaming Tow'r
Had been my funeral Pile!—Why was I spar'd,
To sink in deeper Woes!—Oh, pitying Heav'n,
If e'er thy Care regarded Innocence,
Restore me to my Lord!

SP.SPEAKER: EGBERT.
SP.L: Behold him here!

SP.SPEAKER: THYRA.
SP.L: Is't possible!—'Tis He! my Lord! my Husband!
Oh happy Change! Oh Bliss unspeakable!
Support me, heav'nly Pow'rs! Support me, EGBERT.
I faint, I faint! Oh, take me to thy Breast!—

SP.SPEAKER: EGBERT.
SP.L: Thou Crown of all my Joys! Thou Cause belov'd
Of all my bitterest Pangs! Do I once more
Infold thee in these Arms!

SP.SPEAKER: THYRA.
SP.L: Too bounteous Heav'n!
And are my Sorrows sled! Shall Hope once more
Visit this Breast? And do I live to see thee!
Alas, my Lord! thro' what unnumber'd Woes,
Thro' what a Sea of Horrors have we past,
Since last we parted!

SP.SPEAKER: EGBERT.
SP.L: Such is Heav'n's high Will.
England is fall'n! The Majesty of Empire
Is sunk by Fate! Destruction rears her Banner:
The fatal Raven croaks; and Britain's weeping Genius,
Yielding his Charge, flits to some happier Clime!

SP.SPEAKER: THYRA.
SP.L: Oh fatal Day! be thou for ever wept!
Yet ev'ry future Morn shall hear my Praise,
And Gratitude sincere arise to Heav'n,
For this dear Boon, this Cure of ev'ry Woe,
That I have found my EGBERT!—Say, my Lord,
Who led thee to these Tents?

SP.SPEAKER: EGBERT.
SP.L: Thro' the wide Waste
Of mortal War, I sought my virtuous THYRA,
To save her from the Foe: But sought in vain.
Then rushing on the thickest War, my Sword
Edg'd by Despair, I mow'd my Way; to where
GOTHMUND, intrench'd in triple Rows of Spears,
Stood like our Country's Fiend. He met my Arm.
But soon th'o' erwhelming Files that hemm'd him round
Ended the mortal Strife; and led me hither,
The Captive of his Pride.

SP.SPEAKER: THYRA.
SP.L: Blest, blest Event!
Sure, 'twas some unseen Angel rul'd thy Fate;
Now, barbarous GOTHMUND, I defy thy Threats!
Oh Coward! to insult a helpless Captive!

SP.SPEAKER: EGBERT.
SP.L: Soul of my Soul! The frowning Fates surround us!
That thou art here, restor'd to Life and Me,
This grateful Tear I offer up to Heav'n!
But if some heavier Ruin hangs unseen,
Unkind and cruel was the Sword that spar'd thee!—

SP.SPEAKER: THYRA.
SP.L: But thou art come, like some blest Pow'r from Heav'n,
To banish all my Fears! Ah, why that Groan?

SP.SPEAKER: EGBERT.
SP.L: Dear THYRA! See,—these Chains!—

SP.SPEAKER: THYRA.
SP.L: Wou'd I cou'd wear them for thee!

SP.SPEAKER: EGBERT.
SP.L: Generous THYRA!
I know thy Love: I do believe thou woud'st.
Think then, what Pangs must rend thy EGBERT's Heart,
To see thy Worth insulted, drag'd by Pow'r
To soul Dishonour; while this cruel Chain
Binds down his honest Vengeance!

SP.SPEAKER: THYRA.
SP.L: Since I have found thee,
Tho' setter'd in this ignominious Chain,
I know not why,—but ev'ry Fear is fled:—
There's Safety in thy Arms.—

SP.SPEAKER: EGBERT.
SP.L: My Soul's best Part!
Wrap not thy Heart in blind Security!
Helpless thou seest me here, as Age or Childhood:—
I fear the rising Storm. Forgive me, THYRA,
If in the Tempest of my Rage, these Chains
Shou'd strike thee to the Earth! the cruel Task
Of desp'rate Love! and blot that Heav'nly Form
With deadly Wounds and Blood; to rescue thee
From this remorseless Dane!

SP.SPEAKER: THYRA.
SP.L: But ATHELSTAN,
Who sav'd me midst the Horrors of this Day—

SP.SPEAKER: EGBERT.
SP.L: Who? Mercia's Duke?

SP.SPEAKER: THYRA.
SP.L: Hath bravely sworn Protection.

SP.SPEAKER: EGBERT.
SP.L: Curse the Traitor!
'Twas he, whose Sword, unsheath'd by lawless Fury
Against his Country, and the best of Kings,
Hath brought Destruction on us.—May his Treason
Fall, like an impious Arrow shot at Heav'n,
And cleave his hoary Head!

SP.SPEAKER: THYRA.
SP.L: Yet, if I err not;
Ere this, Conviction of his Crime hath wrought
Repentance in his Heart.

SP.SPEAKER: EGBERT.
SP.L: No: plead not for him:
He hath undone us all!

SP.SPEAKER: THYRA.
SP.L: Forgive me, EGBERT,
If Gratitude work strong within my Soul.—
He sav'd me from the Dane. A Mind so noble,
Tho' headlong driv'n down by the Tide of Passion,
Must soon return to Virtue.

SP.SPEAKER: EGBERT.
SP.L: Cou'd I hope it?
Cou'd I but hope he wou'd rejoin our Arms,
We yet might rescue Thee, and rescue England!

SP.SPEAKER: THYRA.
SP.L: Behold, he comes!—Now, EGBERT, curb thy Rage,
Think: He is still the Guardian of my Honour.
Assume the winning Eloquence of Grief,
Lab'ring beneath it's Wrongs: His generous Heart
Will melt in Sympathy.

SP.SPEAKER: EGBERT.
SP.L: My virtuous THYRA,
For thee, and for my bleeding Country's Sake,
I'll choak the Pang I groan with.—

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: Down, proud Heart!
Oh, I am rent with Anguish! Never more
Shall fair Peace keep her Sabbath in my Breast!
Unthankful Dane!

SP.SPEAKER: SIWARD.
SP.L: What less cou'd Reason fear
From unrelenting Robbers?

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: Blind Revenge!
Oh whither hast thou led me!—Say, proud Captive,
Who brought thee to these Tents?

SP.SPEAKER: THYRA.
SP.L: Brave ATHELSTAN,
This is my Lord, my EGBERT.—Honor'd EGBERT,
Lo, Mercia's Duke, who sav'd me from Dishonour.—

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: Yet, rul'd by sullen Pride, he scorns to thank me.

SP.SPEAKER: EGBERT.
SP.L: That thou didst save her from the Rage of War,
Binds me thy Friend: But that thy trait'rous Arm
Hath madly drawn thy Sword against thy King,
Unties that private Bond of Man with Man,
And bids me stand thy Foe.

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: To injur'd Honour
A brave Revenge was due.

SP.SPEAKER: EGBERT.
SP.L: Oh ATHELSTAN!
Thy Vengeance, in its fatal Course, hath swept
Thy Friends and Foes in one promiscuous Ruin!
Childhood and Age, the Gentle and the Brave,
And helpless Innocence which never wrong'd thee,
Have felt the Fury of thy mad Revenge.
Had'st thou been England's Friend, these bloody Danes,
Had fled our Shores: No Briton then had drag'd
These ignominious Chains! nor helpless THYRA
Had call'd in vain on Earth and Heav'n to save her!

SP.SPEAKER: THYRA.
SP.L: Dire is our Fate's Decree, when EGBERT weeps!
Oh cruel GOTHMUND!

SP.SPEAKER: EGBERT.
SP.L: False, false ATHELSTAN!

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: No more:—Why rend ye thus my tortur'd Heart?
Thy Words are Scorpions in my Breast.—Rash Man,
Take back thy THYRA:—Guard her as thou can'st:—
Farewell: I'll hear no longer.—

SP.SPEAKER: THYRA.
SP.L: Gen'rous Duke!
Leave us not thus! Leave us not to Destruction!
We have no Hope but thee!

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: Thy tears are vain.—

SP.SPEAKER: SIWARD.
SP.L: Spurn not her Griefs—

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: SIWARD, if thou'rt my Friend—

SP.SPEAKER: EGBERT.
SP.L: Nay, but thou yet shalt hear me:—Across thy Steps
I'll throw my Body, tho' thy Hand were arm'd
With Lightning, till thou hear me—

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: Urge me not:
Urge not thy Fate—

SP.SPEAKER: EGBERT.
SP.L: Alas! can Fate do more!
Oh ATHELSTAN! but that I know thy Virtues,
I wou'd not stoop t' intreat thee. Life I reck not.
Then spite of thee, I dare to be thy Friend:—
Yes; I will search thy Heart; will there dethrone
Usurping Passions that have banish'd Reason,
Eclips'd thy Virtues in their noon-tide Sphere,
And darken'd all their Brightness!

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: Let me pass—

SP.SPEAKER: EGBERT.
SP.L: By Heav'n, I will not, till I have paid the Debt
Due to thy generous Soul.—Yes; thou hast been
My THYRA's guardian Genius:—Hear me now,
Hear Me, as thine: Sent by all-gracious Heav'n,
Kindly to warn thee of that Sea of Guilt,
In which thy Rage hath plung'd thee!—Hear the Voice
That calls thee, to return to Honour's Path;
Bravely to quit thy guilty League with Denmark,
And save poor bleeding England!

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: Witness Heav'n,
How dear hath England's Happiness and Fame
Been to my Soul! How, on this dreadful Morn,
When Vengeance led me to the Field of Death,
My bleeding Heart wept for my Country's Woe,
And half subdu'd Revenge!—Behold these Tears—
These Tears proclaim, I am a Briton still!

SP.SPEAKER: EGBERT.
SP.L: Then act a Briton's Part.—

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: Ungrateful King!
Why didst thou wake my Rage! why urge my Vengeance
To lead Destruction on!

SP.SPEAKER: EGBERT.
SP.L: Nay, wrong him not.
'Tis Passion's Blindness rules thee.—Heav'n and Earth
Witness the untir'd Bounties of his Hand.
But when bold Expectation, nurs'd by Vanity,
Brooks no Denial; and assumes to weigh
Its own fantastic Worth;—what earthly Pow'r
Can satisfy it's Cravings, or fill up
Th' unfathom'd Measure of Self-Love and Pride!

SP.SPEAKER: SIWARD.
SP.L: Or grant thy Worth neglected:—Grant the Slave,
Fool, Flatterer, Whisperer, reptile Sycophant,
To thee prefer'd in Honour:—Virtue still,
Wrapt in the Majesty of calm Disdain,
And self reyer'd, in her own Dignity
Wou'd check Revenge; wou'd welcome Injury
With manly Scorn, and for the publick Weal
Forget all private Wrong.

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: No more, no more!
Wou'd Heav'n, I had not done it.—

SP.SPEAKER: EGBERT.
SP.L: Imperial London!
Fair England's Boast! The Glory of the Isles!
How art thou fall'n! Thy Palaces and Tow'rs,
Low level'd with the Dust, now smoke in Ashes!—
Heav'n! as we pass'd in Chains the Streets along,
How the loud Shrieks of ravish'd Maids and Matrons,
The Groans of Britons weltring in their Blood,
Of Infants writhing on the bloody Spear,
Transfix'd my Heart!—

SP.SPEAKER: THYRA.
SP.L: In vain the holy Priest,
The trembling Sire, and widow'd Wife, in vain
Clung to their Altars, and implor'd for Mercy:—
The Ruffian Foe with sacrilegious Hand
Dragg'd them to Death; and to his Idols grim
Did shed their innocent Blood!—

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: What have I done!
Oh Britain! hapless Britain!

SP.SPEAKER: SIWARD.
SP.L: Dost thou weep?
Come, fair Repentance, Daughter of the Skies!
Soft Harbinger of soon returning Virtue!
The weeping Messenger of Grace from Heav'n!
Lovely in Tears.—Now melt his generous Heart!
Infuse kind Pity for his Country's Woes!
Wake his great Soul; and bid him shine once more,
It's Pride, Support, and Glory!—

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: 'Tis too late!
Oh Madness! Headlong Madness!

SP.SPEAKER: EGBERT.
SP.L: Ne'er too late
To turn to Virtue!—THYRA, SIWARD, kneel;
And sue for Mercy to our ruin'd Country!—

SP.SPEAKER: THYRA.
SP.L: Cou'd a poor helpless Captive's Pray'r be heard!—

SP.SPEAKER: EGBERT.
SP.L: Behold in us, Millions of guiltless Britons—

SP.SPEAKER: SIWARD.
SP.L: Pleading for Life and Freedom!—

SP.SPEAKER: EGBERT.
SP.L: Hear the Groans
Of martyr'd Christians—

SP.SPEAKER: THYRA.
SP.L: Bleeding for their Faith—

SP.SPEAKER: SIWARD.
SP.L: Imploring Help from thee!—

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: Rise, Britons, rise.—
I yield, I yield!—Yes; England, I am thine!—

SP.SPEAKER: EGBERT.
SP.L: Oh happy Change!

SP.SPEAKER: SIWARD.
SP.L: Oh generous ATHELSTAN!

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: And yet—to stoop!—meanly to sue for Pardon!—

SP.SPEAKER: SIWARD.
SP.L: He, he alone degrades his State, who stoops
To wrongful Deeds; these done, 'tis truly brave
To sue for Pardon, and who stoops, is greatest.

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: Come to my Heart! my Friends! my Guides to Peace!
Your Words, like Light from Heav'n, have pierc'd my Soul!
Oh Blindness, Frenzy!—Gen'rous, injur'd King,
How can I e'er behold thee!

SP.SPEAKER: EGBERT.
SP.L: Trust his Goodness.
His chief Delight is Mercy: and when Justice
Demands the awful Sacrifice of Life,
Reluctant he confirms the harsh Decree.

SP.SPEAKER: SIWARD.
SP.L: Ev'n now a trusty Spy return'd, informs me,
Our valiant King, must'ring his scatter'd Pow'rs,
Ere Morning dawns will storm the Danish Camp:
Lead but thy valiant Mercians—

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: Grant me, Heav'n,
On a wide Heap of routed Danes to die!
I ask no more.—Come, let us quit the Camp.—

SP.SPEAKER: EGBERT.
SP.L: Alas, brave Duke, I am a Captive here.
I cannot go. A thousand guiltless Britons
Must bleed, shou'd I escape.—But to thy Care,
Here I bequeath a Trust more dear than Life.
Let THYRA be the Partner of thy Flight.

SP.SPEAKER: THYRA.
SP.L: Must I then leave my Lord!
Severe Decree! Shall I not see my EGBERT,
Ere I depart?

SP.SPEAKER: EGBERT.
SP.L: My ever honour'd Wife,
Be sure thou shalt.

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: THYRA, retire: and while I seek the Dane,
To lull Suspicion, wait us in thy Tent,
Prepar'd for Flight.—Now SIWARD, to my Mercians.—
Tell them my Wrongs from Denmark: paint the Pangs
Of my unfeign'd Repentrance: rowze their Valour
To quenchless Rage, that may atone my Guilt.
That to the Ghost of ev'ry martyr'd Briton
We slew in Fight, a Host of Danes may die.

SP.SPEAKER: GOTHMUND.
SP.L: HER Husband, did'st thou say?

SP.SPEAKER: GOODWIN.
SP.L: So Rumour speaks.

SP.SPEAKER: GOTHMUND.
SP.L: Amazement—Then he hath play'd false with HAROLD,
And quench'd my Hope.—Did'st thou not say, thou saw'st him,
Walking-the Camp?

SP.SPEAKER: GOODWIN.
SP.L: He shot athwart the Tents
With proud and hasty Step, that seem'd to scorn
The Ground he trod.

SP.SPEAKER: GOTHMUND.
SP.L: Then we shall meet him here.
This is his Wife's Pavilion. If he comes,
I mean to speak him fair. Persuasion mild
Shall first allure Consent: Shou'd that be vain,
From the false Calm a sudden Storm shall rise,
And bury him in Ruin.—Is the Guard
Arm'd, and at Hand to seize him?

SP.SPEAKER: GOODWIN.
SP.L: Arm'd, and ready.

SP.SPEAKER: GOTHMUND.
SP.L: Behold, he comes.

SP.SPEAKER: GOODWIN.
SP.L: 'Tis he: I see his Chain,
That glitters in the Moon-beam.

SP.SPEAKER: GOTHMUND.
SP.L: GOODWIN, hence:
Wait within Call.—

SP.SPEAKER: GOTHMUND.
SP.L: Briton, I greet thee well.
Is the fair Captive won to GOTHMUND's Love?
Why art thou dumb?

SP.SPEAKER: EGBERT.
SP.L: Why do I see thee here?

SP.SPEAKER: GOTHMUND.
SP.L: Lest Insult shou'd approach fair THYRA's Tent,
I come to watch her Welfare.

SP.SPEAKER: EGBERT.
SP.L: As the Wolf
Guards the defenceless Lamb.

SP.SPEAKER: GOTHMUND.
SP.L: Hast thou forgot
Whose Chain thou wear'st?

SP.SPEAKER: EGBERT.
SP.L: 'Tis Thine: and thence I scorn it.

SP.SPEAKER: GOTHMUND.
SP.L: EGBERT, beware: Thou know'st the Victor's Pow'r:
Wake not his Rage.—

SP.SPEAKER: EGBERT.
SP.L: I bear a guiltless Mind,
Thou can'st not conquer.—

SP.SPEAKER: GOTHMUND.
SP.L: Hence, audacious Captive.
I know thee THYRA's Husband.—Tremble, Briton:
Nor sport with angry Pow'r!

SP.SPEAKER: EGBERT.
SP.L: Hence, ruffian Dane!—This Tent is ATHELSTAN's.
THYRA's his Captive: and kind Heav'n ordain'd him,
To rescue Innocence from Lust and Rapine.

SP.SPEAKER: GOTHMUND.
SP.L: Yet I am calm.—But have a Care, rash Youth—
For ATHELSTAN:—What Pow'r but mine can shield him
From the just Vengeance of his injur'd King?
Whate'er the Traitor won, he won for me.
Like these rich Territories, THYRA'S mine
By Conquest: Let not then weak Shame or Pride
Obstruct the Victor's Wish: Be just, brave EGBERT,
And yield her Beauty to its new Possessor.

SP.SPEAKER: EGBERT.
SP.L: Come, honest Pride! Oh fill my swelling Heart,
And arm mine Eye, and point my Tongue with Scorn,
Keen as the Scorpion's Sting!—By Heaven, this Chain,
This Chain alone bids Insolence be bold,
Which else were dumb, as Cowardice or Guilt!
Oh, for my honest Faulcion! which this Morn,
O'erwhelming Numbers wrested from my Hand!
Yes: I wou'd hunt thee thro' the Battle's Rage:
Surrounding Guards, and doubling Ranks in vain
Should shelter thee!

SP.SPEAKER: GOTHMUND.
SP.L: Hell's Curses blast thy Pride!
Had not the busy Guards forestall'd my Vengeance,
The Lightning of my Sword had cleft thee down.
Shall I bear this? Hoa, GOODWIN! Bring the Guard!
Seize that insulting Captive: Drag him hence,
To dark Imprisonment, and seven-fold Chains,
Till the Fleet sail for Denmark.

SP.SPEAKER: THYRA.
SP.L: Mercy, Mercy!
Oh GOTHMUND, at thy Feet!

SP.SPEAKER: GOTHMUND.
SP.L: Let go thy Hold.—
Quick, bear him to his Prison.

SP.SPEAKER: EGBERT.
SP.L: Why this Violence?
I am your Captive: Bear me where ye may.

SP.SPEAKER: THYRA.
SP.L: Must we thus part!—Oh cruel Dane! In Mercy
Destroy us here together!

SP.SPEAKER: EGBERT.
SP.L: Strive no more:
Waste not thy generous Tears on barbarous Pow'r:
For what can Right, when Lust and Madness rule?
Yield to thy Fate. Farewell!

SP.SPEAKER: THYRA.
SP.L: My Lord! my EGBERT!
Oh lost, lost, lost!—

SP.SPEAKER: GOTHMUND.
SP.L: Thou yet hast Pow'r to save him.—

SP.SPEAKER: THYRA.
SP.L: Oh name the Task which Honour sanctifies,
And I will die to save him!—Bid me roam,
An Exile from my Country, thro' the Climes
Where frozen Lapland's wintry Wastes extend;
Doom me for ever to th' unwholesome Mine,
Where hopeless Slav'ry toils:—I'll bless my Fate,
So I may save my EGBERT.

SP.SPEAKER: GOTHMUND.
SP.L: Fear not, THYRA,
So harsh a Doom—That delicate Frame was form'd
For gentler Offices.—Crown but my Love,
And EGBERT shall be free.

SP.SPEAKER: THYRA.
SP.L: Peace, Monster, Peace!
Nor wound my chaste Ear with thy Words, which taint
The wholesome Air.

SP.SPEAKER: GOTHMUND.
SP.L: Else shall my Vengeance sweep
Thy stubborn EGBERT to far distant Shores.
Yes: he shall dwell with Darkness, pine with Want,
Rot 'midst the cold Damps of a hideous Dungeon;
And live a ling'ring Death!

SP.SPEAKER: THYRA.
SP.L: Oh horrible!
Thou can'st not mean it!

SP.SPEAKER: GOTHMUND.
SP.L: By our Gods, I do!
While thou, the Minion of the general Camp,
Shalt feed unbridled Lust; till wrinkled Age
Doom thee at length a household Drudge, the Scorn
Of loathing Appetite!

SP.SPEAKER: THYRA.
SP.L: Oh hear me Heav'n!
Hear me, thus kneeling, low on Earth! Descend,
Ye guardian Pow'rs that watch o'er Innocence,
Descend, and soften his relentless Heart,
Or I am lost for ever!—Hear me, GOTHMUND,
For the chaste Matron's Sake, who gave thee Birth!
Oh, hear!

SP.SPEAKER: GOTHMUND.
SP.L: Nay, yield thee; or his Fate is seal'd.—

SP.SPEAKER: THYRA.
SP.L: Pity my captive State! a helpless Orphan,
With not a Friend! an outcast from my Country!
Unknown to all; ev'n to myself unknown!
A poor lost Infant, wreck'd on England's Coast!
Perhaps an Infant Dane!—Oh why, EDWINA,
Why was I rescued by thy Father's Hand!
Else had my Sorrows found a peaceful Grave
In the devouring Deep!

SP.SPEAKER: GOTHMUND.
SP.L: An infant Dane?
Give me but Proof of That—

SP.SPEAKER: THYRA.
SP.L: Concurrent Proofs
Bespeak me such: Wrong not thy Country then:
Wrong not thy Friends: Oh think thou seest thy Friends,
And thy dear Relatives now plead in me;
And thus with bended Knees and lifted Eyes
Beseech thy Pity!—speak, EDWINA, speak!
Oh tell the Tale of Woe! The mournful Tale
Needs not the colouring of artful Tongues,
To melt the hardest Heart!

SP.SPEAKER: GOTHMUND.
SP.L: I charge thee, Woman,
Be bold in Truth: or instant Death awaits thee.

SP.SPEAKER: EDWINA.
SP.L: Hear then the Tale, which at the hallow'd Altar
I dare confirm.—Near to the Coast of Wessex
My Father liv'd; an humble Villager.
'Twas on a Time when Storms had vex'd the Deep,
We spy'd a Danish Vessel driv'n on Rocks,
Then swallow'd in the Flood. The Storm rag'd on:
And on the rolling Billows, mountain-high,
This helpless Babe came floating. The next Wave
Had wash'd her to the Deep: 'Twas then my Father
Snatch'd her from Death.—Soon as our Cottage Warmth
Recall'd her into Life, the lovely Babe
Smil'd on us, all unconscious of her Woe.
Tears gush'd from ev'ry Eye. My generous Father,
Generous tho' poor, and now a Saint in Heav'n,
Embrac'd the Child, and vow'd her as his own.
Beauty, with ev'ry winning Quality,
Grew with her Growth: She was our Village Pride.
EGBERT at length, drawn by her peerless Fame,
Beheld, and lov'd, and won her.

SP.SPEAKER: THYRA.
SP.L: Generous EGBERT!

SP.SPEAKER: GOTHMUND.
SP.L: But say—Did this poor Babe alone survive
The general Wreck?

SP.SPEAKER: EDWINA.
SP.L: Alone: The rest were swallow'd
By the devouring Flood.

SP.SPEAKER: GOTHMUND.
SP.L: But tell me, Woman,
Why did ye judge the sinking Wreck, a Dane?

SP.SPEAKER: EDWINA.
SP.L: 'Twas from the yellow Streamers, hoisted high
In Signal of Distress.

SP.SPEAKER: THYRA.
SP.L: Behold this Chain,
By me held sacred from my earliest Age:
This, haply, may confirm the wondrous Tale.

SP.SPEAKER: EDWINA.
SP.L: That very Chain adorn'd her infant Neck:
Inwrought with mystic Figures, it hath tir'd
Each letter'd Sage's Eye.

SP.SPEAKER: GOTHMUND.
SP.L: The Signatures
Are of a Runic Import: which our Bards,
And Priests, and Sages magic-taught, can spell.
I'll bear it to their Search.

SP.SPEAKER: THYRA.
SP.L: May Heav'n infuse
Soft Pity to thy Heart!

SP.SPEAKER: GOTHMUND.
SP.L: Cou'd I but win
Fair THYRA's Love!—The Camp shall pour its Trea∣sures:
Freedom and Wealth, the Spoils of conquer'd England,
Shall join to grace thy Tent: while thou supreme
Shalt triumph o'er thy Fate, and bless the Hour
That spoke thy Birth, and gave thee to the Dane.

SP.SPEAKER: THYRA.
SP.L: Oh mighty GOTHMUND!

SP.SPEAKER: GOTHMUND.
SP.L: Nay, dry these Griefs; tho' much indeed they grace thee.
Come; let thine Eyes beam with their own soft Fires,
And all thy Form awaken into Beauty.
Dwell not with fruitless Woe: Lot bitter Tears
Rain from the Captive's Eye, condemn'd to Exile,
And endless Slav'ry: But a happier Lot
Awaits fair THYRA's Choice, and pleads Acceptance.

SP.SPEAKER: THYRA.
SP.L: My EGBERT! O my Husband!

SP.SPEAKER: GOTHMUND.
SP.L: Weep no more;
Thy Tears can ne'er recall him.

SP.SPEAKER: THYRA.
SP.L: Little know'st thou;
What strong eternal Bands of mutual Love
Have knit our Souls: Divided Happiness
We ne'er can know. Joy, like one common Sun,
Must shine on Both or Neither: and if Night
Hath overcast his Fate; my Sun of Life
With his, is set for ever.—Give me the Chain.—

SP.SPEAKER: GOTHMUND.
SP.L: Nay, by my Sword, the Chain
Is dearer to me than a Diamond's Mine.
This Chain's the Clue, shall guide me to thy Birth;
Which, once reveal'd, shall ev'ry Tie dissolve
That binds thee to these Britons. Denmark then
Shall claim thee Her's; and GOTHMUND plead her Rights.

SP.SPEAKER: THYRA.
SP.L: Unfriended Innocence implores in vain!
EDWINA, range the Camp! seek out my EGBERT!
Tell him, his THYRA kneels in vain for Mercy,
And bid him fly to save her!—Oh, I rave!
E'en now, reientless Ruffians bind him down,
In the drear Depth of dark Imprisonment;
Far from his helpless THYRA.

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: Sure, the Voice
Of Female Lamentation struck mine Ear.—
THYRA!—whom do I see?—What, drown'd in Tears?

SP.SPEAKER: THYRA.
SP.L: Oh, lost, for ever lost!—This barbarous Dane!

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: What of him?

SP.SPEAKER: THYRA.
SP.L: Bent to do a Deed of Horror,
Ev'n now he hath dragg'd to dark Imprisonment
My guiltless Lord!—He threatens instant Violence!

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: Curs'd be the Day on which he touch'd our Shores!
Come; let us from the Camp:—Ere this, my Mercians,
Warn'd of th' Oppressions of this bloody Dane,
And touch'd with Pity for their Country's Woes,
Burn to rejoin their King.—Come, gentle THYRA,—
EDWINA, come.—My Presence shall protect you,
Safe thro' this hostile Camp.

SP.SPEAKER: THYRA.
SP.L: Too generous, Duke!
Can I desert my Lord!

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: Then stay, till GOTHMUND—

SP.SPEAKER: THYRA.
SP.L: Oh, save me, ATHELSTAN!
Haste, let us hence!—I have no Help but thee!
Alas, my virtuous EGBERT, must I leave thee!

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: Nay, fear not for him:—Ere yon Moon hath rode
Her Circuit round the Skies, I'll pour my Thunder
On these accursed Danes, and give him Freedom.
SIWARD, ere this, throughout the Ranks hath wak'd
Brave Discontent, and kindled all my War.—
Come, let us quit the Camp.—

SP.SPEAKER: GOODWIN.
SP.L: Hear, ATHELSTAN!
Our General sends thee Greeting.—Sacred ever
He deems the Rights of War: yet Pow'rs ally'd
Own the Priority of peaceful Claim.—

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: 'Tis granted.—What of this?—

SP.SPEAKER: GOODWIN.
SP.L: That captive Fair,
Won by thy Prowess in the City's Storm,
By Law of War is Thine: An earlier Right
Our General pleads: For Proofs of Circumstance
Speak her by Birth a Dane.

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: No false Pretence
Shall wile her Virtues from me.—THYRA, speak:—
Is't not a feign'd Pretence?

SP.SPEAKER: THYRA.
SP.L: Oh mighty Duke!
Tho' Ruin hangs upon the Acknowledgment;
I fear, I am a Dane; and thence unworthy
A generous Briton's Care!

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: Wrong not thy Worth:
For, as within the Forest's howling Depth,
Where grifly Bears, and Pards, and Tigers roam,
The wild Rose blooms; So oft in savage Lands
Untutor'd Virtue dwells: Where'er 'tis found,
It claims Defence: Virtue is Virtue's Care,
Alike in ev'ry Clime.—Then tell me, GOODWIN,—
For ere I yield my Captive, I will know:—
What Proofs of Circumstance—

SP.SPEAKER: GOODWIN.
SP.L: Behold this Chain—
With Runic Characters—

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: Ye Pow'rs of Heav'n,
That weave th' inextricable Maze of Fate!
What do I see!—If 'tis your sacred Will
To make me blest, now lend a pitying Ray!
This very Chain, my once victorious Arm
Rent from the proud Neck of a slaughter'd Dane.—
Oh Joy, Oh Grief! Oh Rapture to my Soul!
How,—when,—where,—whence? Speak, GOODWIN!
Or Hope and Doubt will heave my Heart to bursting!

SP.SPEAKER: THYRA.
SP.L: Ah me! I was a helpless Infant, lost
Ere Mem'ry yet was seated in the Brain!

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: Oh blessed Hope! Such was my EMMA too!—
EDWINA,—can'st thou tell?—Range, range the Round,
Where Mem'ry hoards her Treasures, and brings back
Old Time! Confirm the Whispers of sweet Hope,
And give me back my Child!

SP.SPEAKER: EDWINA.
SP.L: Heav'n! dost thou weep
A Daughter lost?

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: And long have wept in vain!—
Since she was lost, full twenty Years have shed
Their various Woes on my poor orphan'd Child!—
When furious HALFDEN ravag'd Mercia's Cities,
Then was my Child (this very Chain she wore!)
Snatch'd from her Cradle by unpitying Danes
And thence convey'd to Denmark's barbarous Shore!

SP.SPEAKER: THYRA.
SP.L: Oh gracious Heav'n!
On that lamented Time,
This very Chain circling her infant Neck,
By my dear Father's Hand was THYRA snatch'd
From the devouring Deep!

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: 'Tis She!—My Child! my Child!

SP.SPEAKER: THYRA.
SP.L: My Father!

SP.SPEAKER: EDWINA.
SP.L: Gracious Heav'n!
Who can behold this Sight, and not dissolve
In Tears of Joy!—

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: And was it mine, to save thee!
Oh Pow'rful Nature!—For since first I saw thee,
My EMMA's Sweetness struck on ev'ry Sense:
Some soft Attraction drew!—some unknown Charm
Work'd in my Soul, and bade me wish thee Mine!—
Haste, GOODWIN, haste to GOTHMUND: there disclose
This Tale of Joy, this wondrous Burst of Bliss!
Tell him, that Nature cancels ev'ry Claim,
And gives my EMMA to her Father's Love!

SP.SPEAKER: GOODWIN.
SP.L: I'll forthwith to his Tent: A Minute's Round
Shall bring thee his Resolve.

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: Eternal Providence!
To whose all-seeing Mind, th' unmeasur'd Round
Of wide Events is present! far beyond
The narrow Ken of a weak mortal Eye!
Deep and unsearchable, yet just and true,
Are thy ador'd Decrees, O Pow'r divine!
Thou ev'n beyond the Darings of fond Hope,
Hast from the Bosom of the raging Seas
Restor'd my long-lost Daughter!—

SP.SPEAKER: THYRA.
SP.L: Happy, happy!
Oh Bliss unspeakable! And do I live,
Thus to be press'd to a fond Parent's Heart!
To hang upon his Breast! To know the Joy,
The heart-felt Raptures that attend the Names
Of Child and Daughter!

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: Darling of my Soul!
Oh Comfort of my Age;—Yet, yet one Grief
Checks the sweet Tumult of my honest Joy!
One piercing Grief lies heavy on my Soul!—

SP.SPEAKER: THYRA.
SP.L: Can I relieve thy Pain?

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: Not all the lenient Balms thy Love can pour,
Can ever give me Rest!—Oh Madness, Madness!
I have undone my Country!

SP.SPEAKER: THYRA.
SP.L: Alas, the Pity!
Think not so deeply of it.

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: Oh, I am vile!
I dare not lift my guilty Eyes to Heav'n!
Yet Heav'n hath show'r'd a Blessing on my Head,
Beyond the World's wide Empire!—What may this mean!—
Sure, 'tis the Prelude to some dire Event!
A passing Gleam, sent by almighty Vengeance,
To deepen future Woe!

SP.SPEAKER: THYRA.
SP.L: Nay, rather deem it
The kind Encouragement of Heav'n, vouchsaf'd
To thy returning Virtue!

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: Heav'n is just,
Yet merciful:—Let me but rescue England,
And I shall yet be blest!—

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE VI.

SP.SPEAKER: GOODWIN.
SP.L: Hear, Mercia's Duke!
GOTHMUND decrees, that ev'ry Right of Peace
Yields to the Conqu'ror's Pow'r; and claims his Captive.

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: Sooner your Swords shall drink my warm Life-blood—

SP.SPEAKER: GOODWIN.
SP.L: Hoa! DUNELM—Bear her off!—

DIV2.STAGE: [DUNELM and the Guard appear, and seize THYRA.

SP.SPEAKER: THYRA.
SP.L: Help! Help! Undone!
Dear Father, help!—

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.STAGE: [Part of the Guardremain and intercept him.
SP.L: Damnation! Treach'ry! Treach'ry!—
Slaves, let me pass—

SP.SPEAKER: GOODWIN.
SP.L: Not this Way, by the Gods—

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: By Heav'n, I'll mow my Passage with my Sword.—

SP.SPEAKER: GOODWIN.
SP.L: Disarm him—

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: Villains! give me back my Daughter!

SP.SPEAKER: GOODWIN.
SP.L: Rave not, old Man!—She now is GOTHMUND'S Charge.

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: Inhuman Dogs!—Tell me—in Pity tell me—
Where is my Daughter! Give me back my Daughter!—
Oh, Mercy, Mercy, Heav'n!—

SP.SPEAKER: EDWINA.
SP.L: Alas, my Lord!
I fear She's lost for ever!—

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: Vengeance! Vengeance—
EDWINA, come!—I'll to this bloody Dane,
And frown him into Stone!—Loud in his Ear
I'll thunder all my Wrongs; and shake his Soul
With Sounds as dire, as when at general Doom
The dreadful Trump shall wake the guilty Dead!
Shou'd he be deaf to injur'd Nature's Claim,—
I'll to my Mercians, and let loose Revenge!
Swift o'er these ruffian Danes I'll pour the Flood
Of War; and drown the guilty Camp in Blood;
Rage thro' their Tents, like fierce consuming Fire;
And among Heaps of slaughter'd Foes expire!

SP.SPEAKER: GOODWIN.
SP.L: IS she secur'd?

SP.SPEAKER: DUNELM.
SP.L: Fast:—Barricado'd strong
By doubled Ranks of Guard: whose levell'd Spears
Hem round the Tent.

SP.SPEAKER: GOODWIN.
SP.L: Did not the Duke of Mercia,
Attempt to wrest her from them?

SP.SPEAKER: DUNELM.
SP.L: Yes: with Fury,
Fierce as the foaming Boar that whets his Tusks,
When the bold Hunter hath destroy'd his Young,
He clamour'd to the Guard. They mock'd his Rage.
Thrice he essay'd, with phrenzy-like Despair,
To pierce their Ranks: Then Fury sunk to Grief.
Melting in Tears, he fu'd for one small Grace:
Pray'd that EDWINA, her late fellow Captive,
Might share her Griefs. His Suit in Sport was granted.
EDWINA now weeps o'er her.—But he comes,
To plead his Right with GOTHMUND.

SP.SPEAKER: GOODWIN.
SP.L: Fierce will be
Their meeting Frown; when Rage encounters Rage;
In either Breast a Storm.

SP.SPEAKER: DUNELM.
SP.L: I'll to my Watch:
E'en let the Tempest roar.

SP.SPEAKER: GOODWIN.
SP.L: My Charge is here.

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: Vile Caitiff! Where's thy General?

SP.SPEAKER: GOODWIN.
SP.L: Fair Words, Briton.
Choak thy foul Breath. The General's in his Tent.
What woud'st thou?

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: Tell him, ATHELSTAN is come.
His Heart will speak the rest.

SP.SPEAKER: GOODWIN.
SP.L: Ev'n now he sits
On secret Council: Nor can Clamour gain
Admittance to his Ear.

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: Insidious Hell-hound!
Or bring us Face to Face; or by yon Heav'n,
His Tent shall be a Cobweb to my Rage.
I'll tear the sheeted Cordage from its Base,
And give it to the Winds: I'll call so loud,
The Heav'ns shall echo me; and the chaste Stars
Eclipse with Horror at th' infernal Deed
Which his fell Heart conceives.

SP.SPEAKER: GOTHMUND.
SP.L: What lawless Clamour
Breaks on my Tent?

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: What lawless Rapine late
Invaded mine?

SP.SPEAKER: GOTHMUND.
SP.L: Thou shalt be answer'd bravely.—

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: I will be answer'd truly.—Think not, GOTHMUND,
That Frowns can terrify; or vile Evasion
Silence my loud-tongu'd Wrongs.—Speak—tell me, Dane,—
Why this audacious Insult on the Rights
Of sworn Alliance, and the Laws of War?

SP.SPEAKER: GOTHMUND.
SP.L: Am I not here supreme?—Whate'er was won,
Was won beneath my Banner. Thou, proud Duke,
Wert but a Wheel within the vast Machine
That tore up England's Freedom. Yes, thy Sword
Was but the Instrument of GOTHMUND's Will.
I was the Soul, the all-directing Pow'r
That rul'd the War: Whate'er ye won, ye won
Each for himself indeed; but all for me.

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: Oh Falsehood, foul as Hell! What Dane so vile,
But now enjoys the Conquest that he reap'd?
Behold th' unpitying Riot of the Camp,
Rich with the Spoils of my poor ruin'd Country!
How ev'ry Soldier lords it o'er the Heap
Of Plunder which he won!

SP.SPEAKER: GOTHMUND.
SP.L: So GOTHMUND wills.
But did so dear a Prize inrich their Tents,
As lately brighten'd ATHELSTAN's;—my Voice,
Swift as the Virtue of a magic Spell,
Shou'd leave them void as thine.

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: Curs'd Insolence
Of barb'rous Pow'r!—Yet think not ATHELSTAN
Roll'd in the sordid List of GOTHMUND's Slaves.
I plead the Law of War; and claim my Captive.

SP.SPEAKER: GOTHMUND.
SP.L: Thine▪

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: Mine: by Right of War.—

SP.SPEAKER: GOTHMUND.
SP.L: Hence, prating Pedant!
Thou shalt be frock'd, and mantled in the Garb
Worn by your Cell-bred Monks.—By Right of War?
Dost thou not see, what Thousands hemm me round,
Dreadful in crested Helms? These plead the Rights
Of GOTHMUND and of Denmark. Think'st thou, Briton,
We touch'd these Shores, to parley with our Slaves
In weak Contention? Violence is our Law.
The Sword is Valour's God: 'Twas thine this Morn:
And now 'tis GOTHMUND'S.

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: Blush, Ingratitude!
What Sword but ATHELSTAN'S!—Down, swelling Heart!
No! heav'nly Pow'rs! I dare not call you down,
In witness to my Wrongs!—Yet this from thee!—
Oh thankless Dane!

SP.SPEAKER: GOTHMUND.
SP.L: Go, preach thy Follies, Christian,
To the obscure and coward Sons of Peace.
I wing a loftier Air; where Eagle-Glory
Soars high above Reproach.—Fair THYRA'S mine.
More dear than half the Spoils of conquer'd Britain.
Thou ne'er shalt see her more.

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: O stern Decree!
Yet hear me, GOTHMUND!—Hear a Parent's Pray'r!—

SP.SPEAKER: GOTHMUND.
SP.L: A Parent's Pray'r!

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: Yes: THYRA is my Child; now scarce restor'd
To the fond Wishes of her aged Father,
Till plung'd in deeper Woe!

SP.SPEAKER: GOTHMUND.
SP.L: THYRA thy Child?
A thin Pretence!—She was an infant Dane;
Snatch'd from a Wreck that sunk on England's Coast.

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: That Wreck was rich with conquer'd MERCIA's Plunder.
My Child was there. Each speaking Circumstance,
The well-known Chain, the fatal Time, the Place,
All rising into Proof, proclaim her mine:
Mine, GOTHMUND, mine: The only Pledge of Love,
Her dying Mother left.—Behold these Tears
That trickle down my Cheek.—Oh think what Pangs
Must inly rend the Heart of ATHELSTAN,
Ere he cou'd weep!—Let gentle Pity then—

SP.SPEAKER: GOTHMUND.
SP.L: Pity! The Foe to ev'ry manly Deed!
The Bane of Victory: a timorous Child,
Scar'd at the gorgeous Pride and Pomp of War;
Fit, only fit, to rule a Woman's Breast!
Avaunt!—I scorn its Cries!—What! Mercia's Duke
Dissolv'd in Woman's Tears?—

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: Yet, there are Times,
When Tears are brave and honest: Such are these:
Ennobled by Humanity and Love.
'Tis Nature pleads within me: Scorn not, GOTHMUND,
Her generous Feelings!—On some future Hour,
When Fate shall frown on Denmark; some dear Child,
Thy Soul's best Treasure, may be torn from thee!
Woud'st thou not weep? Oh, timely wise, beware!
Nor heap an injur'd Father's Curses on thee!

SP.SPEAKER: GOTHMUND.
SP.L: Is this brave ATHELSTAN? Beneath whose Spear
Squadrons have sunk, unequal to its Rage?
The Warrior's sled. Hence, Dotard, hence: and take
Th' effeminate Staff and Spindle; best befitting
A Soul so like a Woman.

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: Hell and Horror!
Pangs! choaking Pangs!—No—burst not yet, my Heart;
Till I have reap'd Revenge.

SP.SPEAKER: GOTHMUND.
SP.L: Revenge? old Man!
Hence, Traitor!—seek for Vengeance where thou may'st.
Haste thee to ETHELRED: go tell thy King,
GOTHMUND hath injur'd thee.—

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: Rush down, ye Heav'ns!
Ye pitying Thunders, rivet me to Earth!
And save me from this Hell-hound's Voice, that shakes
My Frame to Dissolution!

SP.SPEAKER: GOTHMUND.
SP.L: Such Reward
Shall ev'ry Traitor find.

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: Oh, I cou'd tear these white Hairs from their Roots!—
Curs'd be the Pine on which ye plough'd the Seas!
Curs'd be th' unhallow'd Breeze that fill'd your Sails!
Curs'd be the Tides that bore you to our Coast!
But doubly curs'd am I, whose headlong Rage—
Yes; righteous Heav'n! with Tears of burning Anguish,
I own thy Justice on me!

SP.SPEAKER: GOTHMUND.
SP.L: Hence, vile Rebel!
Hence,—nor pollute my Camp. For know, that Treason
And prostituted Faith, like Strumpets vile,
The Slaves of Appetire, when Lust is sated,—
Are turn'd adrist to dwell with Infamy,
By those that us'd them.

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: Oh, for my honest Sword!—I burn, I burn!
And Hccla's Fires are here!—Th' invenom'd Shast
Drinks up my poison'd Spirit.—Come, wild Fury!
Come with thy Blood-shot Eyes, and mad'ning Foam!
Oh, nerve me to the ten-fold Strength of Phrenzy!
That I may rend up Rocks and rooted Trees,
And hurl Destruction on him!

SP.SPEAKER: GOTHMUND.
SP.L: Quit my Tent:
Think'st thou, a Warrior crown'd with Glory's Wreath
Can dread the Foam of headlong Rage? Or stand
Aw'd by the Phrenzy of a Madman's Brain!
Hence! vent thy Ravings to the stormy Seas:
They'll heed thee, more than I.—

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: Yes: I will go.—
Thou think'st me helpless, friendless, and disarm'd:
Yet shalt thou rue my Wrongs.—By Heav'n I'll come
In Terror clad; more dreadful than the Pest
That walks in midnight Darkness.—Yes: I'll go.
But, barbarous Dane!—Take heed of my Return!

SP.SPEAKER: GOTHMUND.
SP.L: Hoa, DUNELM!
Guard each Avenue of the Camp.
Forbid yon Traitor's Egress: If he attempt
To 'scape the Watch, arrest him: For his Heart
Labours with Ruin: He is false to Denmark.—
Go, credulous Dotard! Cou'd thy Folly hope
To win the Friendship of thy Country's Foe?
Ev'n such, thro' ev'ry Age, shall be the Lot
Of British Blindness, when it aids Invasion:
The Slave of Conquest first; and then her Scorn:
The Scaffolding on which Ambition mounts;
Then spurns it to the Earth, a Refuse vile,
Fit for Contempt to tread on.—Welcome, HAROLD,
Hast seen our Captive EGBERT?

SP.SPEAKER: HAROLD.
SP.L: Aye, my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: GOTHMUND.
SP.L: Didst thou declare my purpos'd Thought?

SP.SPEAKER: HAROLD.
SP.L: I did.

SP.SPEAKER: GOTHMUND.
SP.L: How did he meet it?

SP.SPEAKER: HAROLD.
SP.L: First, with frantic Rage
He shook his Chains, and curs'd thee by his Gods.
I told him, Rage and frantic Banns were vain.
If he resign'd fair THYRA to thy Arms,
(Since only He cou'd win her to thy Wish)
Freedom was his. But if his stubborn Pride
Shou'd thwart thy Will; To-morrow's Breeze shou'd waft him
To Chains, to Darkness, and the dreary Depth
Of Norway's mine: while she, imprison'd here,
The Vassal of Desire, shou'd sate thy Wish.

SP.SPEAKER: GOTHMUND.
SP.L: Did not the threatned Vengeance bend his Pride?

SP.SPEAKER: HAROLD.
SP.L: A sullen Pause took Place. His fixed Eyes
Devour'd the Ground: as if some mighty Thought
Labour'd within him; and to secret Council
Call'd inward ev'ry Pow'r; that for a while
Each idle Sense stood vacant.

SP.SPEAKER: GOTHMUND.
SP.L: What ensu'd?
That Pause from Rage did, sure, bespeak Consent.

SP.SPEAKER: HAROLD.
SP.L: It did. Yet with evading Speech he answer'd,
Cannot thy General wait some happier Hour,
When Time hath heal'd her Woes?—On that, I told him,
Unconquerable Passion swell'd thy Breast;
He might as soon controul the Tides, impell'd
By yon fair Planet's Influence.—

SP.SPEAKER: GOTHMUND.
SP.L: Aye: tho' Storms,
And raging Seas conspir'd with ev'ry Orb,
To drown the lofty Shore!

SP.SPEAKER: HAROLD.
SP.L: Such was my Hint.—
He said, the burning Blush wou'd stain his Cheek,
Shou'd the surrounding Guard that led him to her,
Witness his Shame: I gave him fix'd Assurance,
That my Command shou'd keep the Guard at Distance:
While he, admitted to her lonely Tent,
Unheard shou'd plead his Life, and GOTHMUND's Love.
On this, he gave Consent.—

SP.SPEAKER: GOTHMUND.
SP.L: Then haste thee, HAROLD.
Bid GOODWIN lead the Captive to his Wife:
See him recall'd: That done, draw off thy Guard
To a more distant Station from her Tent.
For ere the Noon of Night, on Passion's Wing
I'll fly, to celebrate the Rites of Love.
Yet wear a watchful Eye, intent tho' distant:
Haply, he means to wile her from our Camp.

SP.SPEAKER: HAROLD.
SP.L: My Life shall answer it.—

SP.SPEAKER: GOTHMUND.
SP.L: At length she's mine.
Deceit hath colour'd o'er my bold Attempt.
Now, fiery ATHELSTAN, go curse thy Folly:
Rave to the Winds and Seas, and rend the Air
With twice their Clamour!—Farewel, valiant HAROLD:
Speed my Resolve: I'll to my inner Tent.

SP.SPEAKER: HAROLD.
SP.L: Now, Vengeance, thou art mine!—Unthankful GOTH∣MUND!
To pay my honest and deep-printed Scars
With vile Neglect!—Go, headlong Fool of Passion!
Whose flattering Whisper cou'd alone infuse
This Dream of Hope, that EGBERT e'er shall stoop
To gather Life from Shame!—Yes, he shall go:
Yet not to mould her into vile Compliance,
But arm her fainting Virtue with new Strength,
Equal to this dread Conflict.—Yet, lest Fear,
Or Woman's Weakness sink beneath the Trial,
A better Hope remains:—MERCIA's brave Duke:—
Yes, injur'd ATHELSTAN! Thy Arm shall be
The dark and fearless Minister of Fate;
And give me deep Revenge.

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: Yet hear me, DUNELM!
For Pity's sake, relent.

SP.SPEAKER: DUNELM.
SP.L: Peace, clam'rous Tongue!

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: What! shall your Guards spurn me with Insolence?
Your barbarous Camp imprison me?

SP.SPEAKER: DUNELM.
SP.L: No more.
Within this Mound, the General's Voice is Law.

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: She is my Child! Art thou, too, deaf to Mercy?

SP.SPEAKER: DUNELM.
SP.L: Vex me not, Briton!

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: But release my Daughter!—
Give me my Child, and let me quit your Camp,—
My Dukedom's Wealth is thine!

SP.SPEAKER: DUNELM.
SP.L: Thy Dukedom's Wealth?
Vain Man! Thy Pow'r is swallow'd up in Conquest:
Thy Titles vanish'd with thy Country's Freedom:
Thy boasted Wealth is fled to Denmark's Shore:
Thy Palace doom'd for Danes to riot in.
Peace then: and thank our Bounty, that we leave thee
Life, and the general Air.—

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: Oh merciless!
Yet, righteous Pow'rs! what Claim have I to Mercy!
Did I shew Mercy, on this fatal Morn,
To my poor bleeding Country; when this Arm
Made Widows childless!—Dar'st thou then, bold Wretch,
Dar'st thou against th' afflicting Hand of Heav'n
To rise, and plead for Mercy!—Rather bow thee
Low in the Dust!—Yes, thou shalt be my Bed,
Cold Earth! Here will I lie, till Anguish end me!
Now rise, ye Ghosts of my wrong'd Countrymen!
Ye Spectres pale, rise with your gaping Wounds,
And hideous Yell!—Bring with you dire Despair
From the dread Caverns of eternal Night,
Where deep she dwells with agonizing Groans,
And sleepless Terrors! Rise, array'd in Blood!
Plant round your Horrors! 'till affrighted Reason
Start from my Brain; and I, the Prey of Phrenzy,
Like the fierce Mountain-Wolf in Madness foaming,
Howl to the midnight Moon!—

SP.SPEAKER: HAROLD.
SP.L: 'Twas sure, the Voice
Of ATHELSTAN.—What! prostrate on the Ground!
Art thou not ATHELSTAN?

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: I am that Wretch
Which once was ATHELSTAN! Fair England's Boast,
I rear'd my Head in Honour: now behold me
Low-level'd with the Earth; a hideous Ruin;
Where, 'midst the Desolations of my Soul,
Despair and Anguish dwell!

SP.SPEAKER: HAROLD.
SP.L: What heavy Woe
Hath weigh'd thee to the Dust?—Speak, valiant Duke.—

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: Whoe'er thou art, Oh leave me to my Pangs!
If thou'rt a Dane; know, I detest and curse thee.
If thou'rt a Briton, waste not generous Pity,
But pour thy Curse on Me!—

SP.SPEAKER: HAROLD.
SP.L: Know'st thou not HAROLD?

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: HAROLD? My Woes had swallow'd all Attention:
Indeed, I knew thee not.

SP.SPEAKER: HAROLD.
SP.L: Why this Despair?

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: Alas, my Child, my Child!—But thou'rt a Dane,
And know'st not Pity!

SP.SPEAKER: HAROLD.
SP.L: Hapless ATHELSTAN!
The Colour of thy Grief indeed is deep:
Thou know'st not half thy Woes!

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: Thy Words are dark.—
Oh my prophetic Soul!—I dare not ask thee.—
But if thou bear'st a Tale, with Horrors fraught,
Which Pity dreads to tell;—In Mercy kill me:
Strike deep thy friendly Sword into my Breast;
For I am robb'd of Mine!—My injur'd Daughter!—
Is it not so?

SP.SPEAKER: HAROLD.
SP.L: The fatal Hour approaches.
For ere the Night hath won the Vault of Heav'n,
GOTHMUND, resolv'd on impious Violation,
Will plunge her in Dishonour.

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: Plagues and Palsy,
Disease and Pestilence consume the Robber,
Infect his Blood, and wither ev'ry Pow'r!—
Oh HAROLD! why,—why did'st thou pierce my Soul
With this heart-breaking Tale!—I knew it not:—
Blast him, ye Fiends!—Why sleeps thy Thunder, Heav'n!

SP.SPEAKER: HAROLD.
SP.L: Know, that Heav'n's Thunder sleeps not.

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: Say'st thou, Dane?

SP.SPEAKER: HAROLD.
SP.L: Heav'n's Thunder sleeps not, if thou dar'st to wield it.

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: By Heav'n, I dare. Where is the flaming Bolt?
I'll hurl it on him, tho' with dire Rebound
It strike me to the Centre!

SP.SPEAKER: HAROLD.
SP.L: Fear not, ATHELSTAN.
Behold it here.—

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: A Dagger! Let me grasp it!—
Oh precious Gift; more precious than the Plank
Thrown to the drowning Wretch!—I'll to his Tent,
And plunge it in his Heart!

SP.SPEAKER: HAROLD.
SP.L: Curb thy fell Rage.
I'll give thee safer Vengeance.

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: Generous HAROLD!—
I know the Wrongs thou bear'st from GOTHMUND's Pride.—
Where?—when?—Oh speed thee; for my Soul's on Fire!

SP.SPEAKER: HAROLD.
SP.L: Know then, I rule the nightly Watch that Guards
Devoted THYRA's Tent.

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: Indeed!

SP.SPEAKER: HAROLD.
SP.L: The Files,
At my Command, shall move to such due Distance,
That by a secret Path I'll give thee Entrance.
Then, when the midnight Spoiler comes—

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: Oh Vengeance!—
By Heav'n, his mangled Arteries shall spout
Fountains of Blood!

SP.SPEAKER: HAROLD.
SP.L: Yet, lest Suspicion wake,
To intercept thy Entrance, or thy Flight—

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: Oh, for some Dane's Disguise!

SP.SPEAKER: HAROLD.
SP.L: I will array thee
In Safety's Garb: Wilt thou be plum'd like GOTHMUND?

SP.SPEAKER: ATHELSTAN.
SP.L: Yes: for Revenge, I'll wear the Shape of GOTHMUND,
Or any Fiend in Hell.

SP.SPEAKER: HAROLD.
SP.L: Come on, brave Duke.
